abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Poverty
            Alleviation (Paraiba) in Brazil were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) Community-driven development(CDD)
            mechanisms can improve the quality and targeting of
            non-project public resources while leveraging complementary,
            parallel funding and deepening the investment stock needed
            for faster poverty reduction; 2) Electricity and water
            supply investments have immediate impact on quality of life
            and are an essential component of productive and many other
            activities/functions; 3) CDD can be an effective mechanism
            for productive investments which integrate small-scale
            producers with markets; 4) Political, bureaucratic and
            financial impediments to implementation require astute
            supervision with clear objectives; 5) Systematic impact
            evaluation requires more intensive focus; 6) CDD can
            effectively target and empower poor rural women; 7) CDD is
            appropriate for ethnic groups and indigenous peoples; 8)
            Loan size should be calibrated to Borrower fiscal capacity;
            and 9) Successful projects require in-country leadership and
            managers of high caliber.
